1338    public static double[][] mixVisibleFOVs(double[][] losMap, double[][]... maps)
1339    {
1340        if(losMap == null || losMap.length == 0)
1341            return addFOVs(maps);
1342        final int width = losMap.length, height = losMap[0].length;
1343        double[][] map = new double[width][height];
1344        if(maps == null || maps.length == 0)
1345            return map;
1346        for(int i = 0; i < maps.length; i++)
1347        {
1348            for (int x = 0; x < width && x < maps[i].length; x++) {
1349                for (int y = 0; y < height && y < maps[i][x].length; y++) {
1350                    if(losMap[x][y] > 0.0001) {
1351                        map[x][y] += maps[i][x][y];
1352                    }
1353                }
1354            }
1355        }
1356        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1357            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1358                if(map[x][y] > 1.0) map[x][y] = 1.0;
1359            }
1360        }
1361
1362        return map;
1363    }
1364    /**
1365     * Adds together multiple FOV maps, but only adds to a position if it is visible in the given LOS map. Useful if
1366     * you want distant lighting to be visible only if the player has line-of-sight to a lit cell. Typically the LOS map
1367     * is calculated by {@link #reuseLOS(double[][], double[][], int, int)}, using the same resistance map used to
1368     * calculate the FOV maps. Clamps the highest value for any single position at 1.0.
1369     * @param losMap an LOS map such as one generated by {@link #reuseLOS(double[][], double[][], int, int)}
1370     * @param basis an existing 2D double array that should have matching width and height to losMap; will be modified
1371     * @param maps an array or vararg of 2D double arrays, each usually returned by calculateFOV()
1372     * @return the sum of all the 2D double arrays in maps where a cell was visible in losMap
1373     */
1374    public static double[][] mixVisibleFOVsInto(double[][] losMap, double[][] basis, double[][]... maps)
1375
1376    {
1377        if(losMap == null || losMap.length <= 0 || losMap[0].length <= 0)
1378            return addFOVsInto(basis, maps);
1379        final int width = losMap.length, height = losMap[0].length;
1380        double[][] map = new double[width][height];
1381        if(maps == null || maps.length == 0)
1382            return map;
1383        for(int i = 0; i < maps.length; i++)
1384        {
1385            for (int x = 0; x < width && x < maps[i].length; x++) {
1386                for (int y = 0; y < height && y < maps[i][x].length; y++) {
1387                    if(losMap[x][y] > 0.0001) {
1388                        map[x][y] += maps[i][x][y];
1389                    }
1390                }
1391            }
1392        }
1393        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1394            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1395                if(map[x][y] > 1.0) map[x][y] = 1.0;
1396            }
1397        }
1398        return map;
1399    }
1400
1401    /**
1402     * Adds together multiple FOV maps, but only adds to a position if it is visible in the given LOS map. Useful if
1403     * you want distant lighting to be visible only if the player has line-of-sight to a lit cell. Typically the LOS map
1404     * is calculated by {@link #reuseLOS(double[][], double[][], int, int)}, using the same resistance map used to
1405     * calculate the FOV maps. Clamps the highest value for any single position at 1.0.
1406     * @param losMap an LOS map such as one generated by {@link #reuseLOS(double[][], double[][], int, int)}
1407     * @param maps an Iterable of 2D double arrays, each usually returned by calculateFOV()
1408     * @return the sum of all the 2D double arrays in maps where a cell was visible in losMap
1409     */
1410    public static double[][] mixVisibleFOVs(double[][] losMap, Iterable<double[][]> maps)
1411    {
1412        if(losMap == null || losMap.length == 0)
1413            return addFOVs(maps);
1414        final int width = losMap.length, height = losMap[0].length;
1415        double[][] map = new double[width][height];
1416        if(maps == null)
1417            return map;
1418        for (double[][] map1 : maps) {
1419            for (int x = 0; x < width && x < map1.length; x++) {
1420                for (int y = 0; y < height && y < map1[x].length; y++) {
1421                    if (losMap[x][y] > 0.0001) {
1422                        map[x][y] += map1[x][y];
1423                        if (map[x][y] > 1.0) map[x][y] = 1.0;
1424                    }
1425                }
1426            }
1427        }
1428        return map;
1429    }
1430
1431    /**
1432     * Calculates what cells are visible from (startX,startY) using the given resistanceMap; this can be given to
1433     * mixVisibleFOVs() to limit extra light sources to those visible from the starting point. Just like calling
1434     * calculateFOV(), this creates a new double[][]; there doesn't appear to be a way to work with Ripple FOV and avoid
1435     * needing an empty double[][] every time, since it uses previously-placed light to determine how it should spread.
1436     * @param resistanceMap the grid of cells to calculate on; the kind made by {@link #generateResistances(char[][])}
1437     * @param startX the center of the LOS map; typically the player's x-position
1438     * @param startY the center of the LOS map; typically the player's y-position
1439     * @return an LOS map with the given starting point
1440     */
1441    public double[][] calculateLOSMap(double[][] resistanceMap, int startX, int startY)
1442    {
1443        if(resistanceMap == null || resistanceMap.length <= 0  || resistanceMap[0].length <= 0)
1444            return new double[0][0];
1445
1446        int width = resistanceMap.length;
1447        int height = resistanceMap[0].length;
1448        double rad = width + height;
1449        double decay = 1.0 / rad;
1450
1451        initializeLightMap(width, height);
1452        light[startX][startY] = 1;//make the starting space full power
1453
1454        switch (type) {
1455            case RIPPLE:
1456            case RIPPLE_LOOSE:
1457            case RIPPLE_TIGHT:
1458            case RIPPLE_VERY_LOOSE:
1459                initializeNearLight(width, height);
1460                doRippleFOV(light, rippleValue(type), startX, startY, decay, rad, resistanceMap, nearLight, Radius.SQUARE);
1461                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1462                    for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1463                        if(light[x][y] > 0.0001)
1464                            light[x][y] = 1.0;
1465                    }
1466                }
1467                break;
1468            default:
1469                for (Direction d : Direction.DIAGONALS) {
1470                    shadowCastBinary(1, 1.0, 0.0, 0, d.deltaX, d.deltaY, 0, rad, startX, startY, decay, light, resistanceMap, Radius.SQUARE, 0, 0, width, height);
1471                    shadowCastBinary(1, 1.0, 0.0, d.deltaX, 0, 0, d.deltaY, rad, startX, startY, decay, light, resistanceMap, Radius.SQUARE, 0, 0, width, height);
1472                }
1473                break;
1474        }
1475        return light;
1476    }
1477
1478
1479
1480    /**
1481     * Given a char[][] for the map, produces a double[][] that can be used with most of the methods in FOV, like
1482     * {@link #reuseFOV(double[][], double[][], int, int, double)}. It expects any doors to be represented by '+' if
1483     * closed or '/' if open (which can be caused by calling {@link DungeonUtility#closeDoors(char[][])}), any walls to
1484     * be '#' or box drawing characters, and it doesn't care what other chars are used (only doors, including open ones,
1485     * and walls obscure light and thus have a resistance by default).
1486     *
1487     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
1488     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class, with clear cells assigned 0.0 and blocked ones 1.0
1489     */
1490    public static double[][] generateResistances(char[][] map) {
1491        int width = map.length;
1492        int height = map[0].length;
1493        double[][] portion = new double[width][height];
1494        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
1495            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
1496                switch (map[i][j]) {
1497                    case '\1':
1498                    case '':
1499                    case '':
1500                    case '':
1501                    case '':
1502                    case '':
1503                    case '':
1504                    case '':
1505                    case '':
1506                    case '':
1507                    case '':
1508                    case '':
1509                    case '#':
1510                        portion[i][j] = 1.0;
1511                        break;
1512                    case '/':
1513                    case '"':
1514                        portion[i][j] = 0.15;
1515                        break;
1516                    case '+':
1517                        portion[i][j] = 0.95;
1518                        break;
1519                    case '.':
1520                    case ',':
1521                    case '~':
1522                    case '^':
1523                    default:
1524                        portion[i][j] = 0.0;
1525                }
1526            }
1527        }
1528        return portion;
1529    }
1530
1531    /**
1532     * Given a char[][] for the map that should use box drawing characters (as produced by
1533     * {@link DungeonUtility#hashesToLines(char[][], boolean)}), produces a double[][] with triple width and triple
1534     * height that can be used with FOV methods like {@link #reuseFOV(double[][], double[][], int, int, double)} in
1535     * classes that use subcell lighting. Importantly, this only considers a "thin line" of wall to be blocking
1536     * (matching the box drawing character), instead of the whole 3x3 area. This expects any doors to be represented by
1537     * '+' if closed or '/' if open (which can be caused by calling {@link DungeonUtility#closeDoors(char[][])}), thick
1538     * vegetation or other concealing obstructions to be '"', any normal walls to be box drawing characters, any cells
1539     * that block all subcells to be '#', and it doesn't care what other chars are used (only doors, including open
1540     * ones, vegetation, and walls obscure light and thus have a resistance normally).
1541     *
1542     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
1543     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class and subcell lighting, with triple width/height
1544     */
1545    public static double[][] generateResistances3x3(char[][] map) {
1546        int width = map.length;
1547        int height = map[0].length;
1548        double[][] portion = new double[width * 3][height * 3];
1549        for (int i = 0, x = 0; i < width; i++, x+=3) {
1550            for (int j = 0, y = 0; j < height; j++, y+=3) {
1551                switch (map[i][j]) {
1552                    case '\1':
1553                    case '#':
1554                        portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =
1555                                portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1556                                        portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] = 1.0;
1557                        break;
1558                    case '':
1559                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1560                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1561                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1562                        break;
1563                    case '':
1564                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1565                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1566                                    /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1567                        break;
1568                    case '':
1569                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1570                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1571                                    /*portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1572                        break;
1573                    case '':
1574                        /*portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =*/
1575                        portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1576                                /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1577                        break;
1578                    case '':
1579                        /*portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =*/
1580                        /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1581                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1582                        break;
1583                    case '':
1584                        /*portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =*/
1585                        portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1586                                /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1587                        break;
1588                    case '':
1589                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1590                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1591                            /*portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1592                        break;
1593                    case '':
1594                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1595                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1596                                    /*portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1597                        break;
1598                    case '':
1599                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1600                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1601                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1602                        break;
1603                    case '':
1604                        portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] = 1.0;
1605                        break;
1606                    case '':
1607                        portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = 1.0;
1608                        break;
1609                    case '':
1610                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1611                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/ 1.0;
1612                        break;
1613                    case '':
1614                        portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] = 1.0;
1615                        break;
1616                    case '':
1617                        /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1618                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1619                        break;
1620                    case '':
1621                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1622                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1623                                    /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1624                        break;
1625                    case '/':
1626                    case '"':
1627                        portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =
1628                                portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1629                                        portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] = 0.15;
1630                        break;
1631                    case '+':
1632                        portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =
1633                                portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1634                                        portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] = 0.95;
1635                        break;
1636                }
1637            }
1638        }
1639        return portion;
1640    }
1641
1642    /**
1643     * Given a char[][] for the map, produces a double[][] that can be used with any FOV methods that expect a
1644     * resistance map (like {@link #reuseFOV(double[][], double[][], int, int, double)}), but does not treat
1645     * any cells as partly transparent, only fully-blocking or fully-permitting light. This is mainly useful if you
1646     * expect the FOV radius to be very high or (effectively) infinite, since anything less than complete blockage would
1647     * be passed through by infinite-radius FOV. This expects any doors to be represented by '+' if closed or '/' if
1648     * open (most door placement defaults to a mix of '+' and '/', so by calling
1649     * {@link DungeonUtility#closeDoors(char[][])} you can close all doors at the start), and any walls to be '#' or
1650     * box drawing characters. This will assign 1.0 resistance to walls and closed doors or 0.0 for any other cell.
1651     *
1652     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
1653     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class, but with no partially transparent cells
1654     */
1655    public static double[][] generateSimpleResistances(char[][] map) {
1656        int width = map.length;
1657        int height = map[0].length;
1658        double[][] portion = new double[width][height];
1659        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
1660            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
1661                switch (map[i][j]) {
1662                    case '\1':
1663                    case '':
1664                    case '':
1665                    case '':
1666                    case '':
1667                    case '':
1668                    case '':
1669                    case '':
1670                    case '':
1671                    case '':
1672                    case '':
1673                    case '':
1674                    case '#':
1675                    case '+':
1676                        portion[i][j] = 1.0;
1677                        break;
1678                    default:
1679                        portion[i][j] = 0.0;
1680                }
1681            }
1682        }
1683        return portion;
1684    }
1685
1686    /**
1687     * Given a char[][] for the map that should use box drawing characters (as produced by
1688     * {@link DungeonUtility#hashesToLines(char[][], boolean)}), produces a double[][] with triple width and triple
1689     * height that can be used with FOV's methods that expect a resistance map (like
1690     * {@link #reuseFOV(double[][], double[][], int, int, double)}) in classes that use subcell lighting. This expects
1691     * any doors to be represented by '+' if closed or '/' if open (most door placement defaults to a mix of '+' and
1692     * '/', so by calling {@link DungeonUtility#closeDoors(char[][])} you can close all doors at the start), any walls
1693     * to be box drawing characters, and any cells that block all subcells within their area to be '#'. This will assig
1694     * 1.0 resistance to walls and closed doors where a line of the box drawing char would block light, or 0.0 for an
1695     * other subcell.
1696     *
1697     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
1698     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class and subcell lighting, with triple width/height
1699     */
1700    public static double[][] generateSimpleResistances3x3(char[][] map) {

1704        for (int i = 0, x = 0; i < width; i++, x+=3) {
1705            for (int j = 0, y = 0; j < height; j++, y+=3) {
1706                switch (map[i][j]) {

1708                    case '#':

1713                        break;

1718                        break;

1722                                    /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1723                        break;
1724                    case '':

1726                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1727                                    /*portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1728                        break;
1729                    case '':

1733                        break;
1734                    case '':

1738                        break;

1743                        break;

1748                        break;
1749                    case '':
1750                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1751                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1752                                    /*portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;

1778                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1779                                    /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
